title: Which guitar, Stratocaster or Telecaster, is the best for what kind of music? - Quora

response.answer_text: For starters, the Telecaster can handle just about anything and everything. That specific guitar has truly stood the test of time and has been used in every genre of music, proving that it’s the real jack of all trades that other guitars aren’t. I would argue that it’s somewhat underrated while the Stratocaster is slightly overrated for the reason that players expect too much out of that guitar. Telecasters are the ideal pick of the two when it comes to rock, hard rock and especially heavy metal. The main reason is because unlike the Strat, the Tele’s bridge pickup is overwound and always crunchy. You won’t have to fiddle with many effects to get a good distortion tone. All you really need is an overdrive, compressor and either delay or reverb, and it’s ready to roll for rock music. With the mini single coil in the neck pickup, the Telecaster can also do Jazz surprisingly well. There are some Jazz players out there who use Telecasters solely for this reason. Stratocasters by nature have high treble response to their pickups. This is something many people do not understand when they buy a Strat and think it is some magical guitar that is going to turn them into Jimi Hendrix or Stevie Ray Vaughan overnight. These players are usually quick to be disappointed and have issue with the pickups being “too bright” or “too thin”. If this is your complaint with the Strat, then trust me, the Strat isn’t the guitar you really want, you want a Telecaster instead. Strats sound best when you have effects dialed in and give it boosts. It’s simply NOT a guitar that you just plug into any amp and expect it to sound amazing. You will have to do a bit of wrangling and work on the tone to get it to sound like how you want. One of the best effects for a Strat is fuzz based overdrive, it works perfectly with those treble-heavy single coils. A compressor also definitely helps without making it sound overpowered. Telecasters are best for Rock music, Heavy Metal and Country. The Stratocaster is better off for Blues, R&B, and Pop. But none of this matters. You can get the proper tones for any of these genres with either guitar.

This is a really difficult question to answer for a few reasons. First and foremost, both guitars share a lot of similar characteristics yet have their share of differences as well. The necks are nearly identical except for the shapes of their headstocks. Yes, that can be a factor towards a differing sound but highly unlikely to be picked up by an everyday listener, so we’ll consider them close to identical. The body shapes are different and as such, the Strat has a little less wood than the telecaster does when taking into account the double cutaway routing and the contouring on the backside, so that does affect the sound a bit. Telecasters tend to have a little more middle, in my experience, as compared to Stratocasters. Also, the classic Strat has a routing so that a tremolo bridge can be inserted, along with the housing for the springs to allow for the bridge to glide down and return to its resting position. Again, this shapes the tone to a degree but not so radically that it would be that noticeable to an average listener. One thing that does shape the tone noticeably is the electronics used in a Strat or Tele, and in this regard I’m going to be a purist and only consider the single coil versions as they were originally designed. The Telecaster has two single coil pickups, the Stratocaster has three. The Telecaster has a three way pickup switch that selects neck, both and bridge. The Stratocaster has a five way switch that gives you neck, neck/middle, middle, middle/bridge, and bridge pickup focus. That provides significant tonal variation, more so than the Telecaster does. In both cases, the sound is bright and fairly “thin” as compared to a guitar that has humbucking pickups (think the Gibson Les Paul or SG or Grestch Electromatics, etc.). Guitars with humbuckers tend to be a bit chunkier and fatter sounding. Note that you can also drop humbuckers into Strats and Teles as well, and they will in turn sound fatter with the pickup change but a little less so than a through the neck design guitar would (and again, the significance of this tonal difference is going to be more subtle than you might think). OK, deep breath… having said all of that, the piece of equipment that shapes your sound the most isn’t even the guitar… it’s the amplifier and what’s between the guitar output jack and the input jack of the amp. All things being equal, if you use the same amp and effects, you will hear a range of differences changing guitars (again, depending on the arrangement of your pickups and the kind of pickups you use). By contrast, you will hear noticeable differences playing the same guitar through a variety of amps, without even adding an effects chain into the mix. The more effects you add, the less noticeable different guitars sound. Point being, you can play jazz, ska, metal, country or any other style you may desire with a Strat or a Tele. To the average listener, with stock configs on each, they won’t know the difference.
